description.narrative:
1. Access to finance for women-owned SMEs: CFL is a good partner for IFC in its efforts to support women-owned SMEs in India given the Company's leading position in the MSME market, including a strong presence in low-income states. Capital First has a strong interest in financing women-owned businesses and can effectively channel IFC's funding to women borrowers across India. Increased availability of well-allocated financial resources will help WSMEs grow and stabilize their businesses, create more jobs and contribute more effectively to boosting productive economic activity.
2. Demonstration effect: This investment will be IFC's first Banking On Women project to be undertaken with an NBFC, thus further solidifying women entrepreneur financing as a sustainable and attractive proposition for financial institutions, and is expected to provide a demonstration effect for other NBFCs in India and elsewhere throughout emerging markets.

table, .k-table{ border-collapse:collapse; width:100%; table-layout:fixed; margin-bottom: 15px;} .k-table, .k-table td, table, table td {outline: 0;border: 1px solid #000; } .k-table td, table td { padding: 5px; } The project involves IFC financing of up to INR 3.4 billion (US$50 million equivalent) to Capital First Limited (CFL or the Company), a Systemically Important Non-Deposit Accepting Non-Banking Financial Company in India . The funding will be used for financing the growth of CFLs lending portfolio to women-owned small and medium enterprises (WSMEs). This investment is part of IFCs strategic target to reach 10 million MSMEs during FY17-21. CFL serves micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) and fast-growing emerging middle class consumers in India. It has a highly diversified loan book of INR 188.00 billion (US$2.8 billion equivalent) as of December 31, 2016, of which 91% consists of MSME and consumer financing. The Company has financed 3.5 million customers to-date in 222 locations, including low-income states, across India.
